newsitem.title: INDONESIA: China defence chief visits Indonesia despite Deng.
newsitem.headline: China defence chief visits Indonesia despite Deng.

text.p: Chinese Defence Minister Chi Haotian met Indonesian Vice-President Try Sutrisno and defence officials on Friday on what Asian diplomats saw as a visit to build better ties with Southeast Asian nations.

The death of China's paramount leader Deng Xiaoping compelled him to cut his five-day visit short by one day, an Indonesian Defence Ministry spokesman said. Chi would leave on Monday to attend the funeral the following day, he said.
This meant Chi would miss a meeting with Indonesia's President Suharto scheduled for Tuesday following Suharto's return from state visits to Cambodia, Laos and Burma.
Chi instead paid a courtesy call on Sutrisno, who visited China when armed forces commander in 1992. Details of their talks were not immediately known.
Chi said on his arrival on Thursday that Beijing was willing to develop lasting relations with Indonesia and promote peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region.
"I think this is part of a whole process of building a better understanding with all ASEAN countries, including Indonesia," a senior Asian diplomat told Reuters.
"The idea is to build more confidence and reduce the threat perception towards China," he said.
China's sovereignty claims in the South China Sea and confrontations with other claimants of potentially oil-rich islands in the area has caused unease in the region.
But Beijing has also sought to allay concerns among the seven members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN), stressing dialogue rather than confrontation.
ASEAN comprises Indonesia, Philippines, Vietnam, Thailand, Brunei, Singapore and Malaysia.
Diplomatic sources saw nothing strange in Chi continuing his Indonesia visit despite the death of Deng. The Chinese leader died from respiratory failure on Wednesday aged 92.
"Deng's death was not a totally unexpected thing. The groundwork and preparations were already in place. There was no need for Chi to rush back in that sense," a diplomat said.
An Indonesian Defence Ministry spokesman told Reuters Chi would visit the holiday island of Bali for a day of relaxation and the military academy in Magelang, central Java.
Indonesia resumed diplomatic ties with China only in 1990 after severing them following a 1965 coup attempt blamed on the Indonesian Communist Party (PKI), which is still officially banned.
